Line 43: Line 43:
=== Hardware support ===
=== Hardware support ===
â
* VMware virtual machines do not support [[FireWire]].<ref name=1394support>{{cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/community/message.jspa?messageID=390865#390865 |title=Does 5.5 support Firewire. If not, is VMWare working on it. |publisher=VMTN |date=[[2006-04-27]]}}</ref>
+
* VMware virtual machines do not directly support [[FireWire]].<ref name=1394support>{{cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/community/message.jspa?messageID=390865#390865 |title=Does 5.5 support Firewire. If not, is VMWare working on it. |publisher=VMTN |date=[[2006-04-27]]}}</ref>
* Older VMware virtual machines provide no direct support for [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] 2.0, but make USB 2.0 devices in the host operating system visible to the guest operating-system as USB 1.1 devices. Workstation version 6.0 added support for USB 2.0 devices.<ref name=ws60_relnotes>{{cite web |publisher=VMware, Inc. |url=http://www.vmware.com/support/ws6/doc/releasenotes_ws6.html#features |title=VMware Workstation 6.0 Release Notes |accessdate=2007-07-19}}</ref>
* Older VMware virtual machines provide no direct support for [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] 2.0, but make USB 2.0 devices in the host operating system visible to the guest operating-system as USB 1.1 devices. Workstation version 6.0 added support for USB 2.0 devices.<ref name=ws60_relnotes>{{cite web |publisher=VMware, Inc. |url=http://www.vmware.com/support/ws6/doc/releasenotes_ws6.html#features |title=VMware Workstation 6.0 Release Notes |accessdate=2007-07-19}}</ref>
* VMware virtual machines provide only experimental support for [[3D computer graphics|3D]] [[hardware acceleration]], via [[Microsoft]]'s [[Direct3D]] 8 API.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/support/ws55/doc/ws_vidsound_d3d.html |title=Experimental Support for Direct3D |accessdate=2007-08-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/virtualization/archives/2007/02/can_3d_graphics.html |title=Can 3D Graphics be Achieved on Virtualization? |accessdate=2007-08-28 |date=[[2007-02-10]] |publisher=InfoWorld}}</ref> A [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xF_CoXsXtk4 video] has appeared on [[YouTube]] that demonstrates several 3D-accelerated games running under VMware Fusion and Mac OS X. The release-notes for Fusion beta 2 include a [http://www.vmware.com/products/beta/fusion/releasenotes_fusion.html#games list] of 3D-accelerated computer-games that can run within Windows XP-based virtual machines.
* VMware virtual machines provide only experimental support for [[3D computer graphics|3D]] [[hardware acceleration]], via [[Microsoft]]'s [[Direct3D]] 8 API.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/support/ws55/doc/ws_vidsound_d3d.html |title=Experimental Support for Direct3D |accessdate=2007-08-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/virtualization/archives/2007/02/can_3d_graphics.html |title=Can 3D Graphics be Achieved on Virtualization? |accessdate=2007-08-28 |date=[[2007-02-10]] |publisher=InfoWorld}}</ref> A [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xF_CoXsXtk4 video] has appeared on [[YouTube]] that demonstrates several 3D-accelerated games running under VMware Fusion and Mac OS X. The release-notes for Fusion beta 2 include a [http://www.vmware.com/products/beta/fusion/releasenotes_fusion.html#games list] of 3D-accelerated computer-games that can run within Windows XP-based virtual machines.
